name: Mystery: From Detective Fiction to True Crime
base_name: Mystery: From Detective Fiction to True Crime
long_desc: Mystery fiction is one of the most enduring and popular literary genres, and there is no doubt that the current media landscape has hugely expanded the concept of the armchair detective to include podcasters, journalists, and true crime addicts. This course provides a better understanding of narrative and genre, as well as social norms around gender and race, by looking at the conventions of mystery fiction and true crime. What can these formulaic genres teach us about storytelling, character development, and narrative point of view What do they reveal about a societys notions of justice and order And how is textual analysis itself an act of detection Texts may include podcasts, documentaries, and newstories classic works by Wilkie Collins, Arthur Conan Doyle, and Walter Mosely and contemporary works by Kiley Reid and Oyinkan Braithwaite

custom_fields.goals: Students should expect to leave with better understanding of literary analysis and improved writing abilities
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should have completed first-year writing and have some interest in literary interest and literary analysis
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Oral presentations, short writing assignments, formal essays, and creative projects. Graduate students will have the opportunity to give teaching demonstrations and devise a self-directed research project.
custom_fields.relevance: The course emphasizes clear writing, critical thinking, and the ability to present and support an argument. It invites students to think about literature in a socio-political context
custom_fields.learning_resources: Most readings will be available on campus, but students may need to purchase some novels
